subject: Re: [junit] Re: How to test private methods in a class.
msgSnippet: ... That s basically correct in general. The problem is that Java doesn t have a real distinction between public and published. If it s public, then it s
messageBody:
Kevin Lawrence wrote:

> I believe Elliote wants to minimize the public API to make it easier to
> use. Martin Fowler has a nice article on using interfaces to achieve the
> same objective.

That's basically correct in general. The problem is that Java doesn't
have a real distinction between public and published. If it's public,
then it's published. Given that we're working in Java (especially Java 5
and earlier; things may get better in Java 6) we have to live with this.
In another language, it might be different; but in Java everything
that's public is published, whether you want it to be or not.

--
